item.title: Reverse Pathway Genetic Approach Identifies Epistasis in Autism Spectrum Disorders
item.description: Meta data of reading Rationale Method and result Meta data of reading Journal: PLOS Genetics Year: 2017 DOI: 10.1371/journal.pgen Rationale It has been found that the common variation contributes more to heritability than what is calculated based on additive model in schizophrenia and ASD. This result suggests that genetic interaction may play a role. Furthermore, the epistatic effect can be larger than marginal one, since the individual effect is subject to strong negative selection (unlikely for disease individual to reproduce) whereas gene-gene interaction is allowed to have stronger effect.

item.title: Modeling Linkage Disequilibrium Increases Accuracy of Polygenic Risk Scores
Statistical Epistasis Is a Generic Feature of Gene Regulatory Networks
item.description: Meta data of reading Main question Method and result in brief Meta data of reading Journal: Genetics Year: 2007 DOI: 10.1534/genetics.106.058859 Main question It has been found that even in yeast, the GWAS analysis of statistical epistasis varies a lot between different genetic variation. The question is whether such difference is due to the different functional dependency patterns between genes (regulatory architecture). Method and result in brief This paper takes the approach that focuses on 12 regulatory motifs and simulates data on the basis of these dynamical system.

item.title: Epistasis — the essential role of gene interactions in the structure and evolution of genetic systems
item.description: Meta data of reading Three meanings of epistasis Comments Epistasis as a tool Epistasis as an obstacle Structure and evolution of complex systems Conclusion References Meta data of reading Journal: Nature Review Genetics Year: 2008 DOI: 10.1038/nrg2452 Three meanings of epistasis Functional epistasis Two genes are physically interacting with each other or functionally related to each other (i.e. in the same/redundant pathways). Compositional epistasis It refers to the deviation from Mendelian segregation ratio.
